quiz_metadata.title: Java List Interface and Implementations Quiz
quiz_metadata.description: This quiz covers the main concepts of the Java List interface, ArrayList, and LinkedList, including their key features, common methods, and use cases.

questions.question_text: What is the List interface in Java?

options.text: A class that implements a dynamic array
An interface in Java's Collection Framework that defines an ordered collection of elements
A data structure that only allows unique elements
A type of map that stores key-value pairs

questions.explanation: The List interface is an interface in Java's Collection Framework that defines an ordered collection of elements, allowing duplicates and maintaining insertion order. (Reference: 00:23)

questions.question_text: What are the two common implementations of the List interface in Java?

options.text: ArrayList and HashMap
ArrayList and LinkedList
LinkedList and TreeSet
ArrayList and HashSet

questions.explanation: The two common implementations of the List interface in Java are ArrayList and LinkedList. (Reference: 00:57)

questions.question_text: What are the three key features of the List interface?

options.text: Order is maintained, duplicates are allowed, and index-based access is not supported
Order is not maintained, duplicates are not allowed, and index-based access is supported
Order is maintained, duplicates are allowed, and index-based access is supported
Order is not maintained, duplicates are allowed, and index-based access is not supported

questions.explanation: The three key features of the List interface are: order is maintained, duplicates are allowed, and index-based access is supported. (Reference: 01:10)

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the add method in the List interface?

options.text: To remove an element from the list
To retrieve an element from the list
To add an element to the list
To get the size of the list

questions.explanation: The add method is used to add an element to the list. (Reference: 01:46)

questions.question_text: How does ArrayList handle insertions and deletions at the beginning or middle of the list?

options.text: It is very efficient and fast
It is slow and costly due to shifting elements
It is not supported
It is only efficient for insertions, not deletions

questions.explanation: ArrayList is slow and costly for insertions and deletions at the beginning or middle of the list due to shifting elements. (Reference: 04:07)

questions.question_text: What is the main advantage of using LinkedList over ArrayList?

options.text: Faster random access
More efficient insertions and deletions at any position
Less memory usage
Better support for concurrent access

questions.explanation: LinkedList is more efficient for insertions and deletions at any position due to its doubly linked node structure. (Reference: 06:24)

questions.question_text: What is the time complexity of accessing an element in a LinkedList by its index?

options.text: O(log n)
O(n)
O(n log n)

questions.explanation: Accessing an element in a LinkedList by its index has a time complexity of O(n) due to the need to traverse the list from the beginning. (Reference: 08:04)

questions.question_text: What is the main disadvantage of using LinkedList over ArrayList?

options.text: Slower insertions and deletions
Slower random access
More memory usage
Less support for concurrent access

questions.explanation: LinkedList has slower random access compared to ArrayList due to the need to traverse the list from the beginning. (Reference: 08:20)

questions.question_text: How does ArrayList handle resizing when it reaches its capacity?

options.text: It throws an exception
It does not resize and becomes fixed-size
It resizes by creating a new array with increased capacity
It uses a different data structure

questions.explanation: ArrayList resizes by creating a new array with increased capacity when it reaches its capacity. (Reference: 04:45)

questions.question_text: What is the typical use case for ArrayList?

options.text: Frequent insertions and deletions at any position
Fast random access and occasional insertions/deletions at the end
Concurrent access and modifications
Storing unique elements only

questions.explanation: ArrayList is typically used for scenarios where fast random access is needed and insertions/deletions are occasional and mostly at the end. (Reference: 05:33)
